TEST #7 is TODAY!

Finish Test #7 Review. Answers are posted here: KEY.

On the test you may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Calculators will be allowed so be sure that you have a functioning graphing calculator and a pencil. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will be well prepared if you can do all of the following:

1. Encipher and decipher with substitution ciphers.
2. Encipher and decipher with Caesar ciphers.
3. Encipher and decipher with affine ciphers in various mods, including identification of good and bad ciphers.
4. Apply the concept of congruence classes.
5. Apply modular arithmetic in three contexts:
a) finding reciprocals in various mods;
b) calculation using mods;
c) solving congruences;.
6. Advise Alice and Bob on the advantages and disadvantages of substitution, Caesar, and affine ciphers.
7. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

table.column: Practice for the test. Be sure to look over all handouts, notes, quizzes, and homework. You need to know all the geometry in Assignments #1–80, including the material in Chapters One–Twelve (through Section 12.3) of the textbook, especially the information on area, dissection, basic right-triangle trigonometry, angles in or near circles, circular segments and sectors, arc lengths and measures, tangents to circles, lengths of line segments in or near circles (Power of the Point), similarity, triangles and other polygons, the Pythagorean Theorem, and Special Right Triangles (30°-60°-90° and 45°-45°-90°). The emphasis will be on areas and circles. There are very few formulas that you have to learn: area of a trapezoid, surface area of a sphere, and surface area of a cone are about the only ones! All the others can (and should) be avoided just by thinking about the problem (assuming, of course, that you know the area of a circle and you know how to dissect flat figures and cylinders).

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Practice for the final exam. The best way to do this is to go back over old tests and quizzes, covering up your solutions and seeing whether you can still do the problems. Redoing old assignments will also be very useful. Finally, be sure you have completed the review problems from the previous assignment.

The final exam will begin promptly at 7:50 AM in Room 8 for students with extra time, or at 8:50 AM in Room 14 for those with regular time. In either case it ends at 10:50 AM. On the exam you will be allowed to use two 3"-by-5" notecards written in your own handwriting. We recommend one unit per notecard side, since we’ve studied four units:
  • Quadratics
  • Exponents & Logs
  • Systems of Equations & Inequalities
  • Crypto & Number Theory
Check out the cover sheet ahead of time so that the format will produce no surprises when you walk into the exam.

You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:
  1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.

  2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.

  3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.

  4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.

  5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.

  6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.

  7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved, and by how much.

  8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.

  9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.

  10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.

  11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.

  12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.

  13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.

  14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.

  15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.

  16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.

  17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.

  18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.

  19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.

  20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.

  21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.

  22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.

  23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.

  24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).

  25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.

  26. Graph linear inequalities.

  27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.

  28. Use the mod operation correctly.

  29. Encipher and decipher with Caesar, substitution, affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers. (You will not need to do the exact RSA calculations as part of the exam — you already did them outside of class in RSA Part Four — but you do need to be able to follow the steps in the process.)

  30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.

  31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.

  32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.

  33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.
Several Algebra II teachers will be offering optional 45-minute review sessions (open to students of all teachers) on the second review day and the first two days of final exams. Please note that the time for the one I'm leading has been changed:

Tue 6/14 11:00 - 11:45 Quarter 2: Exponents & Logs Mr. Davidson 200
Wed 6/15 11:00 - 11:45 Quarter 3: Systems of Equations & Inequalities Mr. Gacs 9

Here are your mini-project instructions: 1) Send me a message in RSA (this should be done by noon on 5/19) 2)If the message can be deciphered, I will send you a reply in RSA. If not I will let you know and you will have to send me a second. 3)You will then have 48 hours to return my message in deciphered form. 4) I will then send you a new enciphered message and public key. You will then have 48 hours to crack the message and send me the text of the cracked message. You must also submit a sheet of paper showing your calculations neatly and accurately.
Some important instructions: Please put your name and block in the subject line of your email. Please send me a message in which the chunks are separated by spaces only. Your grade will be determined by how many attempts you need to complete all steps successfully. Please make sure you know exactly what you are doing before the process begins!

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Here are your mini-project instructions: 1) Send me a message in RSA, using my public key to encipher. Also, send me your public key so that I can communicate with you. My public key is n = 10194739, e = 941 (This should be done by noon on 5/20.)
2) If your message can be deciphered, I will send you a reply in RSA. If not, I will let you know and you will have to send me a second message (you will lose some points if this happens, so be careful!).
3)You will have 48 hours to return my message in deciphered form.
4) I will then send you a new enciphered message and public key. You will have 48 hours to crack the message and send me the text of the cracked message. You must also submit a sheet of paper showing your calculations neatly and accurately.
Some important instructions: Please put your name and block in the subject line of your email. Please send me a message in which the chunks are separated by spaces only. Your grade will be determined by how many attempts you need to complete all steps successfully. Please make sure you know exactly what you are doing before the process begins!

table.column:
Practice for the test. Be sure to look over all handouts, notes, quizzes, and homework. You need to know all the geometry in Assignments #1–86, including the reading in the link in Assignment #85 and of course the material we covered in Chapters One–Twelve of the textbook, especially the information on lateral area, total surface area, volumes, and Platonic Solids. Go back and look at the places where we consolidated or replaced certain theorems. For areas and volumes you should be able to handle spheres, cylinders/prisms, and cones/pyramids, as well as ratios of areas and volumes in similar solids.

Bring your graph-paper notebook to class on the day of the test, and hand it in at the beginning of the period. Don’t forget!

If sphere A has 183 times the surface area of sphere B, and sphere C has twice the surface area of sphere B, find the ratio of the volume of sphere C to the volume of sphere A. Round off your answer to the nearest thousandth.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Practice for the final exam. The best way to do this is to go back over old tests and quizzes, covering up your solutions and seeing whether you can still do the problems. Redoing old assignments will also be very useful. You may also want to try these additional practice problems, which will be helpful even though they're not comprehensive. Answers to the non-textbook problems are also available; they are guaranteed to be mostly correct.

On the exam you may use a notecard (≤ 8.5 by 11 inches) written in your own handwriting. You may write on all six sides if you wish.

The exam will start promptly at 8:50. Be sure to go to the correct room:
B Block Room 16
D Block Room 25
Extended time Room 5
The exam will include numerical problems (2-D, 3-D) and proofs (2-D only) on the following topics:
  1. Angles, lines, line segments, & planes (complements/supplements, parallels, perpendiculars, midpoints, etc.)
  2. Congruent triangles (SAS, SSS, ASA, AAS, HL, CPCTC)
  3. Triangle properties (medians, altitudes, concurrencies at various “centers”, Angle Bisector Theorem)
  4. Equidistance Theorems and Midline Theorem
  5. Quadrilaterals (including the hierarchy)
  6. Polygons and polyhedra (including isosceles triangles, angles & diagonals in regular polygons, and Platonic solids)
  7. Similar figures and proportions (including similar right triangles)
  8. Pythagorean Theorem & special right triangles
  9. Right-triangle trigonometry
  10. Equations of lines, midpoints, slopes, intersections, distance
  11. Circles (radii, chords, arcs, angles, tangents, power of the point, sectors, circular segments)
  12. Area, perimeter, and volume (including surface area and scale factors)

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Practice for the final exam. The best way to do this is to go back over old tests and quizzes, covering up your solutions and seeing whether you can still do the problems. Redoing old assignments will also be very useful.

The final exam will begin promptly at 8:50 AM on Thursday, June 16th (rooms to be determined). On the exam you will be allowed to use two 3"-by-5" notecards written in your own handwriting. We recommend one unit per notecard side, since we’ve studied four units:

      * Quadratics
      * Exponents & Logs
      * Systems of Equations & Inequalities
      * Crypto & Number Theory

Don't forget to bring the following items with you to the final exam:

      * two pencils, with erasers
      * two 3"x5" notecards, written on both sides
      * a graphing calculator with fresh batteries


You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:

      1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.
      2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.
      3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
      4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.
      5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.
      6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.
      7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved, and by how much.
      8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.
      9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.
      10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.
      11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.
      12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.
      13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.
      14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.
      15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.
      16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.
      17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.
      18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.
      19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.
      20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.
      21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.
      22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.
      23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.
      24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).
      25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.
      26. Graph linear inequalities.
      27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.
      28. Use the mod operation correctly.
      29. Encipher and decipher with Caesar, substitution, affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers.
      30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.
      31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.
      32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.
      33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

table.column:
Data Types


Read chapter 2 and chapter 3 in the online textbook.

In this — and all subsequent function definitions — you must include a contract, a purpose statement, and at least one test case.

Download Data-Type.py and complete the following excercises:
  • Utopia's tax accountants always use programs that compute income taxes even though the tax rate is a solid, never-changing 15%. Define the functions gross_pay, tax, and net_pay.
    Assume an hourly rate of $12.
    Note:
    "gross pay" is what you earn before taxes.
    "net pay" is what you take home after taxes are deducted.
  • The local supermarket needs a program that can compute the value of a bag of coins. Define the function sum-coins. It consumes four numbers: the number of pennies, nickels, dimes, and quarters in the bag; it produces the amount of money in the bag.
  • An old-style movie theater has a simple profit function. Each customer pays $5 per ticket. Every performance costs the theater $20, plus $.50 per attendee. Develop the function total-profit. It consumes the number of attendees (of a show) and produces how much income the attendees produce. Solution

table.column:
Branching

Read chapter 4.1 - 4.8, 4.10, and 4.12 in the online textbook.

Download Branching.py and complete the following exercises:
  1. Develop a function called can_vote that consumes a person’s age and produces a boolean that tells you whether the person is old enough to vote.

  2. Write a program that consumes a number representing a student’s percentage score on a test and produces a string representing an appropriate comment for that student. For example, teacher_comment(72) might produce "should try harder".

  3. Use symbols for the days of the week.
    Write a function is_weekday that consumes a day of the week symbol and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the day is a weekday.

  4. Write a program begins_with_vowel that consumes a string and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the word begins with a vowel.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column: In class, we clarified the answers to yesterday's warm up, then worked on a new, two-problem warm up. The first problem was about dividing a square into two triangles with a diagonal, the second involved equilateral triangles. After going over the solutions, we moved on to a sheet titled, "Sine, Cosine, and Tangent: Ratios or Functions?" and worked on that for the remainder of the block. HW - finish the Sine, Cosine, Tangent sheet.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column: In class, we some warm up problems involving functions and simplifying expressions involving radicals. (The functions were Michael, Dwight, and Creed.) After that, we then went over questions about the Sine, Cosine, and Tangent worksheet from last time. It took a majority of the period. Late in the block, we went to the Mac Lab to work on a sheet titled, "Morphing Right Triangles with Sketchpad." Most people got through the first of four problems as the bell rang. HW - none. (We'll pick up on the Morphing Right Triangles next time.

table.name: assgts_2010_on

We then began work on a new sheet titled, "Functions: Graphically, Algebraically, Numerically, and Verbally." In addition to those different ways of representing data, we took notes on independent and dependent variables, domain and range, and asymptotes. We then began the three problems in class. HW - finish the three problems.

table.name: assgts_2010_on

We then went on to work on a sheet titled, "Kate Nowak" on the front, and "Slope, Simplify, Graph" on the back. We went over the solutions. HW - be sure the Nowak/Slope, Simplify, Graph sheet is in order.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column: In class, we received solutions for the Sine, Cosine, Tangent sheet and reviewed any lingering questions. Next, we did a brief recap of important review-type items that have come up in class so far; rationalizing denominators (both root and conjugate), SOHCAHTOA and its associated domain, 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles, root of product/quotient rules, and the composition of functions. After that, we talked about the idea of expanding domains and how in math, there is a recurring idea that often when you first learn a new function, you initially work in a relatively restricted domain. As you understanding of that functions expands, you often expand the domain; this is what we've been doing with Trig functions. We then did the first problem from the Morphing Right Triangles sheet, reviewed a little bit about Sketchpad, then headed off to the lab. In that lab, we worked on problems 2 and 3 - most people did not get to number 4. HW - nothing new; see me for extra help/support if you've been struggling.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Iteration and Strings


Read chapter 6 and chapter 7 in the online textbook.

Download Iteration-Strings.py and complete the following exercises:
  1. Write a program called pig that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the simplest dialect of Pig Latin, in which you move an initial consonant (if any) to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "tringsay" and "easy" becomes "easyay"). You may want to use the begins_with_vowel program that we developed in class.

  2. Write a program called pigg that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the dialect of Pig Latin in which you add "way" to a word that begins with a vowel (so "easy" becomes "easyway"), otherwise you move any initial consonants to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "ingstray").

  3. Challenging: Write a function piggy that correctly handles the cases where y is a vowel as in the word myth . It must also handle the case where y is a consonant as in the word year.

  4. Very Challenging: correctly handle words with no vowels such as tsk or cwm.

Finally, students went back and revisited the Rhombus problem from the Sine, Cosine, Tangent worksheet; they were asked to examine the ratio of the longer diagonal to the side of a rhombus with a 135 degree angle. (It was called the Rho(x) function.) HW - finish up Rho(135) question, come see more for help if you're struggling with algebraic manipulation issues or with other problems.

table.column:
Data Structures - Lists


Read chapter 9.1 - 9.16 in the online textbook.
Read the Google Python List Reference and then do the following:
  1. Develop the function contains_doll, which consumes a list of strings and determines whether one of them is "doll".
    Create enough test cases to completely test your code.

  2. Develop the function contains_string, which consumes a string and a list of strings and determines whether or not the string occurs in the list.

  3. Hopefully you used the "in" operator supplied by Python when doing the previous exercises. Now implement your own version of "in" by looping through all the strings on a list looking for a given string.

  4. Define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns the sum of the numbers in the list.

  5. Define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns whether or not a given number is in the list.

  6. Challenging: Define a function that increments each number on the list by a given amount and returns the updated list.

  7. More Challenging: Define a function that consumes a non-empty list of numbers and returns the largest number.

  8. Even More Challenging: Write an "in" function that is data-type independent.

  3. t(x) = (x + 2)2 + 1
  4. u is shown in this graph:

Recursion


Read chapter 11.6 - 11.8 in the online textbook and then do the following:
  1. Write a recursive function that consumes a number(n) and produces n factorial.

  2. Write a recursive function that consumes a number(n) and produces a list of the first n Fibonacci numbers.

  3. Challenge: Have your code raise an appropriate exception if it receives a bad user input value.

    4. If your functions have "ugly" interfaces then write "wrapper" functions that provide a clean interface to the user.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
In class, and on the last assignment, you analyzed a set of wrapping functions for a square path.

Now sketch graphs for a diamond-shape path, where the guards walk straight from each of the following points to the next, eventually returning to the starting point and wrapping around the diamond again and again: (3, 0); (0, 4); (–3, 0); (0, –4). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called diamx, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called diamy, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called diamang.

Finally, sketch three similar graphs for a circular path, where the guards walk around a circle centered at the origin, starting at (1, 0). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called xc, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called ys, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called rad.

table.column:
The following procedure always leads to the same number, called Kaprekar’s Constant. Try it for at least two numbers.
1. Take any four-digit number, using at least two different digits. (Leading zeros are allowed.) 2. Arrange the digits in ascending (smallest to largest) and then in descending (largest to smallest) order to get two four-digit numbers, adding leading zeros if necessary. 3. Subtract the smaller number from the bigger number. 4. Go back to step 2, and continue this process until you see a repeating pattern...
Is there a similar constant for 3-digit numbers? If so, find it! How about 5-digit numbers?

Practice for the test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504, in which case you must arrange for the extra time in advance and must begin and end the test on the same day.

As preparation for the test, I strongly suggest that you do these practice problems. Answers will be posted on Wednesday.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
  2. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines, geometric description, computer program), represent a function in the others.
  3. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
  4. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved, and by how much.
  5. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
  6. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).
  7. Tell whether a relation is a function or not.
  8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
  9. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

TEST #1 is TODAY!

Practice for the test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504, in which case you must arrange for the extra time in advance and must begin and end the test on the same day.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
     1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
     2. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines, geometric description, computer program), represent a function in the others.
     3. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
     4. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x^2 has been moved, and by how much.
     5. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
     6. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x^2 or higher term).
     7. Tell whether a relation is a function or not.
     8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
     9. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Download the following files:

Modify Ball.py and Ballgame.py to do the following:
  1. Make the ball move.
    Hints:
    • Write the body of move_ball_horz and move_ball_vert.
      Add dx to x and dy to y.
    • Modify the key-press function to accept the arrow keys as input.
      When an arrow is hit change the value of dx or dy as appropriate.
  2. Add the ability to change the color of the ball by pressing a key.
  3. Add collision detection and make the ball bounce off the walls
  4. Challenge: Add the effect of gravity.
  5. Very Challenging: Add mouse event handling and drag or throw the ball.

table.column:
• Complete the error analysis of your test. Show your test and the error analysis to your parents; you may keep the test, but you will hand in your error analysis on Monday.

  • Carry out the instructions at the bottom of Constructions I, and perform constructions #1–6 on Constructions II.

  • Remember to make an appointment to see me in order to assess your geometry notebook. Deadline for this is Monday, Oct. 31.

  • Deadline for Test #1 retakes is Friday, November 4. If you are planning to take advantage of this opportunity, you must meet with me first to ensure that you are ready for the retake. (Perhaps you would like to combine this meeting with your notebook check.)

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
• Read Section 3.6, and take notes.

  • Section 3.6, p. 146, #6, 7, 10, 13.

  • Learn how to do the constructions for a perpendicular bisector of a given line segment and a perpendicular to a line from a given point not on the line (pp. 668–669).

  • Pick one of those constructions, and write a two-column proof showing that your construction really does what it claims to do.

  • Using an entire page, draw a large random scalene triangle with a lot of blank space around it, and construct the perpendicular bisectors of all three sides of the triangle.

  • Using an entire page, draw a large random scalene triangle with a lot of blank space around it, and construct the three altitudes of the triangle.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
• The deadline for notebook checks has been extended until Friday, 11/4.

  • Read Section 3.7, and take notes.

  • Section 3.7, p. 153, #5, 13, 14, 16.

  • Draw a large random scalene triangle with a lot of blank space around it, and construct the centroid of the triangle.

  • Consider ΔOAK with these vertices:
    O(0, 0)
    A(24, 0)
    K(16, 14)
    Let the midpoint of side OA be H. (Why H?)
    Let the midpoint of side OK be M. (Why M?)
    Let the midpoint of side AK be F. (Why F?)
    Calculate the coordinates of H, M, and F. Then find the equations of two of the medians of ΔOAK. Finally, find the coordinates of the centroid of ΔOAK.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
• As announced in class, calculators are allowed from now on (except for the very rare quiz where you might be told that they are forbidden).

  • Read Section 3.8, and take notes.

  • Section 3.8, p. 159, #10, 12, 15, 16.

  • Prove that the incenter of a triangle is the intersection of the angle bisectors. (To do this, you will need to know that radii of the inscribed circle ending at the sides of the triangle are perpendicular to those sides.)

  • Draw a large random scalene triangle with a lot of blank space around it, and construct the incenter of the triangle.

  • Redraw points O, A, K, H, M, and F from the preceding assignment. Then find the equations of two of the altitudes of ΔOAK. Finally, find the coordinates of the orthocenter of ΔOAK.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
• Redraw points O, A, K, H, M, and F from the preceding assignment. Then find the equations of the perpendicular bisectors of two of the sides of ΔOAK. Finally, find the coordinates of the circumcenter of ΔOAK.

  • Read my essay on “Levels vs. Tracks” at http://blog.larrydavidson.com/2011/11/02/levels-vs-tracks. (This was written for adults, not for high-school students, but so what? You should read it anyway.) Then send me an email message containing a sentence or two about your own personal experiences with levels in math courses. You may want to tell me whether you learned something new from reading it. I will publish some of your comments (anonymously, of course).

  • Chapter 3 Review Problems, p. 163, #6, 7, 14, 17.

Practice for the test. Be sure to look over all handouts, notes, quizzes, and homework. You need to know all the material in Assignments #1–25, including the material in Chapters One–Three of the textbook, especially the information on angles, properties, congruent triangles, isosceles triangles, circles, and proofs. You also need to know the info on constructions and the various centers of a triangle.

If you want additional practice problems, try these representative (but definitely not comprehensive) examples. (Pay no attention to the problems behind the curtain, such as #9–11. You can also ignore #7, since we haven’t yet done clock problems.) Answers are available here.

1. Sketch a graph of x = sin(y).
  2. Compare your graph with the calculator’s graph of y = sin–1(x).
  3. Do the equivalent pair of tasks for both cos and tan.
  4. Find the domain and range for all six functions: sin, cos, tan, sin–1, cos–1, tan–1.
  5. What do you conclude about the relationships between the trig functions and their inverses?

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
TEST #2 is TODAY!

Finish Review Problems for TEST #2.
Answer are posted here: Answers to "Review for Test #2"

Study for the test. This is best done by redoing problems from previous homework and quizzes, as well as the previous test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must still begin and end the test on the same day. You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:

     1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
     2. Translate expressions and functions from NetLogo to algebraic notation and vice versa.
     3. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines, NetLogo), represent a function in the other three.
     4. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
     5. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved or stretched, and by how much.
     6. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
     7. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs, their tables, and their algebraic rules.
     8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
     9. Find the inverse of a function by backtracking and by graphing.
     10. Convert between forms of quadratic functions (standard, vertex, factored).
     11. Solve quadratic equations by backtracking, completing the square/backtracking, zero product property, factoring/zero product property, and Quadratic Formula.
     12. Identify or find the vertex, x-intercepts, and y-intercept given any form of a quadratic function.
     13. Be able to identify the number of solutions given any function.
     14. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

table.column:
Practice for the test (which has been postponed to 11/7 because of unforeseen events). This is best done by redoing problems from previous homework and quizzes, as well as the previous test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504, in which case you must arrange for the extra time in advance and must begin and end the test on the same day. You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
  2. Translate expressions and functions from NetLogo to algebraic notation and vice versa.
  3. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a function in the other three.
  4. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
  5. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved and by how much.
  6. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
  7. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).
  8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
  9. Find the inverse of a function by backtracking and by graphing.
  10. Complete the square.
  11. Convert a quadratic from one form to another (graphing, standard, factored).
  12. Find the x- and y-intercepts of a quadratic function.
  13. Solve quadratic equations by backtracking and/or factoring.
  14. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Complete at least half of the review for Test #3. If you don’t have time to do all of it, pick sample questions of each type; then finish the rest over the weekend.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Practice for the test. If you need practice on exponent rules, finish Ms. Gajewski's review sheet.

You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Graph exponential functions and create them from their graphs and/or tables.
  2. Find the output for a given input.
  3. Find the growth factor, initial value, and equation for given data.
  4. Use the quadratic formula to solve equations.
  5. Find an input for a given output (by table or guess-and-check).
  6. Perform linear, quadratic, and exponential regression, and use r 2 to determine which is best.
  7. Use growth/decay rate vs. growth/decay factor.
  8. Calculate interest.
  9. Compare tables and graphs of functions (linear, quadratic, exponential).
  10. Apply the properties of exponents.
  11. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
1. Practice for Test #3. Be sure to look over all handouts, notes, quizzes, and homework. You need to know all the material in Assignments #13–34, especially the information on angles, properties, congruent triangles, isosceles triangles, parallel lines, equidistance, definitions and hierarchy of quadrilaterals, and proofs, except that you will not be responsible for logic, transformations, indirect proof, or constructions on this test.

    An optional review session will be held after school on Friday, 12/9, at 3:00 in Room 5. If you want additional practice, try these representative (but definitely not comprehensive) problems. Here are the answers .

  2. Bring your graph-paper notebook to class on the day of the test, and hand it in at the beginning of the period. Don't forget!

  • Section 5.4, p. 239, #14, 15, 16, 17.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:

    • Parallelograms #2, 3, 4.
    • Rectangles #3, 4.
    • Kites #2.
    • Rhombi #4, 5.
    • Isosceles trapezoids #1, 3, 5. [Do these work under both definitions?]

  • Section 5.5, p. 247, #17, 21, 23, 28 [find to the nearest hundredth of a degree rather than the nearest second], 29.
An optional review session will be held after school on Friday, 12/9, at 3:00 in Room 5.

table.column:
TEST #3 is TODAY!
To study, finish the Test 3 Review. Here are the Test 3 Review Answers..

You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:

     1. Graph exponential functions and create them from their graphs and/or tables.
     2. Find the output for a given input.
     3. Find the growth factor, initial value, and equation for given data.
     4. Find an input for a given output (by table or guess-and-check).
     5. Perform linear, quadratic, and exponential regression, and use r^2 to determine which is best.
     6. Use growth/decay rate vs. growth/decay factor.
     7. Calculate interest.
     8. Compare tables and graphs of functions (linear, quadratic, exponential).
     9. Apply the properties of exponents.
     10. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Finish reading Plato’s “Allegory of the Cave.” (You may want to start over again from the beginning, even though we've read more than half of it aloud in class.) Then write or type answers to the following questions:
  1. Some readers think that the people in Plato’s cave are seeing shadows of real objects. For instance, they see a shadow of a dog, though they imagine that they are seeing a real dog. But it’s actually even more indirect than that. Explain what the people are really seeing. (Hint: Read section 515a again.)

  2. When we draw a square, to what extent is it really a square? Be specific!

  3. Suppose we constructed the square. How does that change your answer to the previous question?

  4. How real is the number –3? How about 1/3? How about 3? Is one of these more real than the others?

  5. Who is the person who “sees the light” in the dialog? If necessary, read section 516 again.

  6. Explain Socrates’ remark in 518c : “Education is not what the professions of certain men assert it to be. They presumably assert that they put into the soul knowledge that isn’t in it, as though they were putting sight into blind eyes.”

  7. Draw a picture of what Plato is describing. Label anything in the picture that won’t be clear to your audience. It doesn’t have to be a work of art, but it does need to show accurately what Plato is describing. Be prepared to share your picture with the class.

table.name: assgts_2010_on

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column: Practice for the test. Be sure to look over all handouts, notes, quizzes, and homework. You need to know all the geometry in Assignments #1–43, including the material in Chapters One–Seven of the textbook, especially the information on angles, properties, congruent triangles, isosceles triangles, circles, equidistance, names of pairs of angles, parallel lines, definitions and properties of quadrilaterals, basic facts about planes, angle sums in polygons, diagonals of polygons, and proofs. In particular, be sure that you know the Midline Theorem, the No Choice Theorem, and the formulas for interior and exterior angles of polygons.

TEST #4 on Logarithmic Functions TODAY!!!
Be sure to finish the Test 4 Review Packet.
Answer Key for Review

Practice for the test. You may use a calculator on only part of the test, and both sides of a 3"-by-5" notecard (which you have prepared in your own handwriting) on the entire test. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
     1. Tell whether a function is linear, exponential, quadratic, power, or none of these.
     2. Apply exponential functions as models of real-world phenomena.
     3. Find the common ratio (growth factor) from exponential data.
     4. Apply the properties of exponents and logarithms.
     5. Represent functions as algebraic rules (formulas), tables, graphs, and function machines.
     6. Distinguish exponential from power equations, and solve both.
     7. Represent exponential functions as their graphs and vice versa.
     8. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

As preparation, you should go over all your recent quizzes, handouts, and homework, as well as your Test #3.

Practice for the test. You may use a calculator on part of the test, and both sides of a 3"-by-5" notecard (which you have prepared in your own handwriting) on the entire test. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Tell whether a function is linear, exponential, quadratic, power, or none of these.
  2. Apply exponential functions as models of real-world phenomena.
  3. Find the common ratio (growth factor) from exponential data.
  4. Apply the properties of exponents and logarithms.
  5. Represent functions as algebraic rules (formulas), tables, graphs, and function machines.
  6. Distinguish exponential from power equations, and solve both.
  7. Represent translated exponential functions as their graphs and vice versa.
  8. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.
As preparation, you should go over all your recent quizzes, handouts, and homework, as well as your Test #3. If you want/need additional practice problems, try this review packet written by a former teacher several years ago. It's not a perfect match, but it's extremely close: just change "Scheme" to "NetLogo" in question #3, change "evaluate" to "solve" in question #11, and note that the author does not always parenthesize the input to a log function. Answers will be posted on Wednesday.

  2. Try to solve the one problem given in Angles and Polygons II (as described in class). You will probably want to use the hints given in class. In addition, here are a few more hints if you need them:
    • If you aren’t using all four of the givens, you’re doing something wrong.
    • If you haven’t constructed at least two more lines (or line segments), you’re probably doing something wrong. Use the points where the arc you drew intersects the sides of the big isosceles triangle (or their extensions).
    • If you haven’t found a pair of congruent triangles, you’re probably doing something wrong.

Test 3 is today! You are allowed to use a notecard and a calculator.

Here is a list of test topics:
• Converting from rectangular coordinates to polar coordinates
• Converting from polar coordinates to rectangular coordinates
• Adding complex numbers
• Subtracting complex numbers
• Multiplying complex numbers
• Dividing complex numbers
• Evaluating powers of " i "
• Evaluating square roots of negative numbers
• Solve quadratic equations with complex solutions
• Check your complex solutions by plugging into the quadratic equation • Plotting polar coordinates on a polar graph
• Giving another name for complex number in polar form
• Raise complex numbers to powers
• Find roots of complex numbers
See me if you have any questions!!!!!

1. Complete Iteration, Part 2.

  2. These questions concern the version of Newton’s method that was shown in class:

    1. In finding the square root of a positive number, what happens when the seed is negative? Can you prove that this conclusion is always correct?

    2. Adapt the algorithm so that you are finding the cube root of a number. Try out your version by finding the cube roots of 8, 9, and –8, using several seeds, both positive and negative. Do you always find the real cube root? Or do you sometimes find a non-real complex root? Does it depend on the seed?

You need to know all the geometry in Assignments #1–53, including the material in Chapters One–Nine of the textbook (through 9.7), especially the information on angles, congruent and similar triangles, equidistance, parallel lines, Pythagorean Triples, special right triangles, angles in polygons, and proofs. In particular, be sure that you know the Pythagorean Theorem, the Angle Bisector Theorem, the Sidesplitter Theorem, and its corollary.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
1. Be sure that the following definitions are in your notebook:
    When iterating any particular function...
    • The Filled-in Julia Set or, preferably, Filled Julia Set (FJS) for that function is the set of all prisoners.
    • The Julia Set for that function is the set of points on the edge or border of the FJS. These are a subset of the prisoners, namely those that can become escapees with the slightest change; their orbit is chaotic.
  2. Complete Exploring Julia Sets I (begun in class).

  3. Do not forget the AMC 12 during C Block on Tuesday, 2/7. This class will go to Room 22, where you will be inspired to do well by guest proctor Mr. Fidler. Attendance is required!

TEST #5 on Systems of Equations TODAY!!! If you are leaving on vacation early, you need to make arrangements to take your test immediately after the vacation.
Be sure to finish the Test 5 Review . Here is the answer key.

If you would like more practice problems to help study for the test, here is the Jeopardy Game from class.

Practice for the test. You may use a calculator on the test, and a one-sided 3"-by-5" notecard (which you have prepared in your own handwriting) on the entire test. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
     1. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by graphing.
     2. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by substitution.
     3. Solve systems of linear equations by elimination.
     4. Write a system of equations from a word problem or story problem and solve it in the prescribed way in order to show your work.
     5. Recognize and create situations where there are no solutions or infinite solutions.
     6. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

table.column:
• Read and study Section 10.1, and take notes on the definitions.
  • If you wish, you can consolidate the section’s three theorems into one. Our first attempt will be “A radius is perpendicular to a chord if and only if it bisects the chord,” but we will tweak that phrasing in class. Put this version (or the theorems in the section) in your notes.
  • Study the three Sample Problems.
  • On p. 444, do problems #10, 12, 14, 19, 21, 22, 24.

table.name: assgts_2010_on

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
1. Read and study Sections 10.2 and 10.3, but definitely do not learn all eight theorems in these sections! The key to condensing the eight theorems into two is to recall what “⇔” means: “A ⇔ B” is pronounced "A if and only if B" and is shorthand for “If A then B, and if B then A.” The authors have used this symbol in the middle of p. 453, where they condense Theorems 79–84 into a single sentence. Take notes accordingly.
  2. Explain why we could legitimately condense their sentence even further by eliminating the words “the same circle or in.”
  3. Use a similar technique to read Theorems 77 and 78 on p. 446 and condense them into a single sentence.
  4. On p. 449, do problems #10, 12, 14.
  5. On p. 457, do problems #19, 20, 22.
  6. Work on your project!

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:

  • You may also want to study the good example of a math paper that was given to you in class ("Fixing Ganache"). It was written by a math teacher, but yours may be equally good. If so, you may want to submit it to the Math Teacher.

Write a detailed progress report for your project. You should include the following:
  • a description of what you have done so far
  • a description of just what you still have left to do
  • a full list of all your sources,
  • an explanation of just what contribution each group member is making and is going to make (be sure to name names).
  • a question that can assess whether your audience has grasped a Big Idea that your work is pointing out or exploring.
One submission per group is sufficient: Write the report together with your group; then pick one representative to email it to me before the end of the day.

table.column:
• Prepare a small but tasteful poster to advertise the Fractal Fair. Regular paper size (8.5"x11") would be fine, although a few larger posters would be nice as well. Be sure to include the name (Fractal Fair), the date (Wed 3/14), the blocks (Activity Period and H Block), the time (10:00–12:15), and the location (Library), as well as an appropriate picture or graphic. Use an image that illustrates your own project if it looks good. Otherwise just pick something fractaly. Get it approved by me before posting it, and then post it somewhere visible and legal. We are looking for one poster per student, although you could do them collectively with your group and make three or more altogether. Extra posters are always welcome!

  • Also, be sure to read What to do before, during, and after the Fractal Fair. Do what it says, including inviting your parents and teachers to the Fractal Fair!

  • Complete Fractal Dimension II.

  • Remember to attend the talk by Prof. Devaney in the Media Center during D Block on Friday. Be on time!

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Be fully prepared for the March 14th Fractal Fair: your project should be completed before the 14th! If you have a poster, model, booklet, or other physical object, bring it to the library promptly at 9:40 on the 14th, and set it up in an appropriate place (Mrs. Metcalf will help you). If you have a PowerPoint or other computer demonstration, you should have duplicate copies, either on someone’s email, a CD, or a flash drive. If it’s on a laptop, don’t ever leave it unattended! You can install any computer materials on a PC in the Library or on your own laptop if you wish.

Since the Fractal Fair goes through lunch period, you can take turns going to lunch; Do not leave your project unstaffed at any point. Also, be sure to remember to remove your materials from the library by the end of the week, and to remove all your advertising posters on the 14th. (Please don’t remove them until the Fair is over, however.)

table.column:
Celebrate Pi Day and practice for the test by redoing old problems from tests, quizzes, classwork, and homework. Also, check out the lessons on matrices that we looked at in class. You can find the Table of Contents in the left sidebar; everything is relevant except for the lesson on linear equations and the end of the lesson on determinants. Here are some practice problems, mostly related to that website. Answers are available here.

On the test you may use both sides of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. If you are legally entitled to extra time, remember that you must complete the entire test within the same day and that you must arrange your extra time in advance.

You will be well prepared if you can do all of the following:
  1. Solve systems of linear equations by graphing, substitution, and elimination.
  2. Write a system of equations from a word problem or story problem and solve it in the prescribed way in order to show your work.
  3. Add and subtract matrices, and identify when these operations are possible.
  4. Multiply a matrix by a scalar.
  5. Multiply matrices, and identify when this operation is possible.
  6. Solve equations involving matrices.
  7. Identify elements and dimensions of matrices.
  8. Find and use the determinant of a matrix (2×2 without a calculator, other matrices with); identify which matrices have determinants.
  9. Find and use the inverse of a matrix (2×2 without a calculator, other matrices with); identify which matrices have inverses.
  10. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

TEST #6 on Matrices and Systems of Equations is TODAY!!!
Be sure to finish the Test 6 Review . Here is the answer key.

Practice for the test. You may use a calculator on the test, and a TWO-sided 3"-by-5" notecard (which you have prepared in your own handwriting) on the entire test. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning graphing calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
     1. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by graphing.
     2. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by substitution.
     3. Solve systems of linear equations by elimination.
     4. Solve systems of linear equations using matrices, with and without a calculator.
     5. Add, subtract, and multiply matrices with or without a calculator.
     6. Find and apply determinants and inverses of 2x2 matrices without a calculator.
     7. Write a system of equations from a word problem or story problem.
     8. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

table.column:
• Practice for Test #6. Be sure to look over all handouts, notes, quizzes, and homework. Here are the answers to the review problems:
    13: 14/3
    16: 5; 7, 9, 5
    19: 20
    20: 110°, 50°
    22: a. Opp sides congruent, since it's a parallelogram; adjacent sides congruent, since they are tangents from the same point; so it's a rhombus.
      b. 60.
      c. 60.
      d. 15 times the square root of 3.
    23: 6, 18
    29: 8:5
    31: 16.68 ft.
    You need to know all the material in Assignments #13–61, especially the information on circles, angles, properties, congruent and similar triangles, isosceles triangles, parallel lines, Pythagorean Theorem in 2-D and 3-D, trigonometry, equidistance, definitions and hierarchy of quadrilaterals, and proofs, except that you will not be responsible for logic, transformations, indirect proof, or constructions on this test. Be sure that you can work successfully with measures of angles and lengths of line segments in and near circles, including those made by chords, secants, and tangents. The Power of the Point and the Arc Concavity Theorem will be very helpful.

  • An optional review session will be held after school on Wednesday, 3/21, at 3:30 in Room 5.

  • Bring your graph-paper notebook to class on the day of the test, and hand it in at the beginning of the period. Don't forget!

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Solve the following: 1) An ancient Chinese problem asks for the least number of gold coins a band of 17 pirates could have stolen. When the pirates divided the coins into equal piles, 3 were left over. When they fought over the extra 3 coins, one of the pirates was slain. When the remaining pirates divided the coins into equal piles, 10 coins were left over. They fought again, and another was slain. Now when they divided the coins none were left over. How many coins did they have?
2) CP XTM IQSN: YEQX ETTEPKPB SM ACLK, CTTXEJSACBKLY BDSXBY YKCXM ELV, USBD C RKCXV, VXKMMKV SP C ZCMDSEPCRLK EQBZSB USBD C ZCSXLY TXEPEQPGKV XKGKVSPO DCSXLSPK, SP BDK LCMB ACBGD DK BDXKU TXT BE RKCX YEQX XXX. UDCB MDEQLV YEQX ETKPSPO AEFK RK?
A[15,2,26]

If you are legally entitled to extra time, remember that you must complete the entire test within the same day and that you must arrange your extra time in advance.

You will be well prepared if you can do all of the following:
  1. Encipher and decipher with substitution ciphers.
  2. Encipher and decipher with Caesar ciphers.
  3. Encipher and decipher with affine ciphers in various mods, including identification of good and bad ciphers.
  4. Encipher with matrix ciphers in various mods, including identification of good and bad ciphers.
  5. Apply the concept of congruence classes.
  6. Apply modular arithmetic in three contexts:
    • finding reciprocals in various mods
    • using mod as a binary operation [such as 28 mod 5]
    • solving congruences [such as 3x +5 ≡ 12 (mod 4)].
  7. Advise Alice and Bob on the advantages and disadvantages of the cryptosystems (other than RSA) discussed in the Big Question.
  8. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

Back to the textbook!
p. 66, #18, 23, 30, 34 (see the instructions above #3), 36, 37, 40.

Here are the answers:
18: (x – 3)^2 (2x + 1)(2x – 1); WolframAlpha will give you an excellent graph.
23: y = (x + 1)(x – 1)(x + 3)^2
30: y = x(x – 1)(x – 2)
34: Here are some examples. Again you can check your sketches by asking WolframAlpha to graph them.
a. y = (x + 1)(x – 1)(x + 2)(x + 42)
b. y = (x + 1)(x – 1)(x + 2)^2
c. y = x^3(x – 1)
d. y = x^4
e. y = x^4 + 1
36: 5, 4, 3, 2, or 1
37: y = –2x^2 (x – 3)
40: P(x) = 0.5x^2(x – 4)

table.column:
Practice for the final exam. The best way to do this is to go back over old tests and quizzes, covering up your solutions and seeing whether you can still do the problems. Redoing old assignments will also be very useful. Finally, be sure you have completed the review problems from the previous assignment.

The final exam will begin promptly at 7:50 AM in Room 7 for students with extra time, or at 8:50 AM in Room 30 for those with regular time. In either case it ends at 10:50 AM. On the exam you will be allowed to use two 3"-by-5" or 4"-by-6" notecards written in your own handwriting. We recommend one unit per notecard side, since we’ve studied four units:
  • Quadratics
  • Exponents & Logs
  • Systems of Equations & Inequalities
  • Crypto & Number Theory
Check out the cover sheet ahead of time so that the format will produce no surprises when you walk into the exam.

You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:
  1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.

  2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.

  3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.

  4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.

  5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.

  6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.

  7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved, and by how much.

  8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.

  9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.

  10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.

  11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.

  12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.

  13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.

  14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.

  15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.

  16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.

  17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.

  18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.

  19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.

  20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.

  21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.

  22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.

  23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.

  24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).

  25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.

  26. Graph linear inequalities.

  27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.

  28. Use the mod operation correctly.

  29. Encipher and decipher with Caesar, substitution, affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers. (You will not need to do the exact RSA calculations as part of the exam — you already did them outside of class in RSA Part Four — but you do need to be able to follow the steps in the process.)

  30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.

  31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.

  32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.

  33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
• Review Problems, p. 595, #11, 12, 17, 19, 21.

  • As you know from its name, an icosahedron has 20 faces. Since each face is a triangle, one might think that it has 60 edges. But actually it has only 30. Explain why it has only 30 edges, and then use Euler's Formula to calculate how many vertices it must have.

    But wait...we never got to Euler's Formula in class! You can figure it out for yourself, if you know that it relates the number of edges, vertices, and faces in any solid with polygonal sides: noting that a cube has 6 faces (F), 8 vertices (V), and 12 edges (E), you can figure out that F + V  = E + k, for some value of k. Calculate this value, and double-check it with a tetrahedron, before you go on to solve the icosahedron problem.

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Final Exam


Check out the cover sheet for the exam.

Time:
  • Exam for students with extended time exam begins at 7:50am
  • Exam for all other students begins at 8:50am

Where:
  • Block B in room 208
  • Block E in room 206
  • Extended Time in room 200

Bring:
  • sharpened pencils and pencil sharpener
  • 8 and 1/2 by 11 inch notecard (all six sides)
  • calculator with fresh batteries
  • brain
  • prayer beads and/or lucky charm

Return textbook to me in math office.

The exam will include numerical problems (2-D, 3-D) and proofs (2-D only) involving the following:
  1. Transformations
  2. Angles, lines, line segments, & planes (complements/supplements, parallels, perpendiculars, midpoints, etc.)
  3. Congruent triangles (SAS, SSS, ASA, AAS, HL, CPCTC)
  4. Triangle properties (medians, altitudes, concurrencies at various “centers”, Angle Bisector Theorem)
  5. Equidistance Theorems and Midline Theorem
  6. Quadrilaterals (including the hierarchy)
  7. Polygons and polyhedra (including isosceles triangles, angles & diagonals in regular polygons, and Platonic solids)
  8. Similar figures and proportions (including similar right triangles)
  9. Pythagorean Theorem & special right triangles
  10. Right-triangle trigonometry
  11. Equations of lines, midpoints, slopes, intersections, distance
  12. Circles (radii, chords, arcs, angles, tangents, power of the point, sectors, circular segments)
  13. Area, perimeter, and volume (including surface area and scale factors)

Try these problems out:
1) Find another pattern in Pascal's triangle that we have not yet discussed in class. Can you give a combinatorial explanation for why it occurs?
2) What is (A+B)^7?
3) Staples is having a 10 for $10 sale on fancy pens. If they come in red, orange, blue, black and green, how many different ways could a person pick out 10 pens?
4) A hand of 5 cards is being dealt from a standard deck. How many ways can the hand be dealt so that all of the cards are spades?

  4. Check out the cover sheet ahead of time so that the format will produce no surprises when you walk into the exam.

  5. Here is some useful info about the exam:

    6. When?

    • 8:50–10:50

    Where?

    • D Block regular time in Room 34
    • G Block regular time in Room 33
    • Extra time in Room 200

    How?

    Bring...
    • sharp pencils
    • sharp brain
    • 8½ × 11 inch notecard (you may write on all six sides)
    • calculator with fresh batteries
    • lucky charm

    What?

    The exam will include numerical problems (2-D, 3-D) and proofs (2-D only) involving the following:
    1. Transformations
    2. Angles, lines, line segments, & planes (complements/supplements, parallels, perpendiculars, midpoints, etc.)
    3. Congruent triangles (SAS, SSS, ASA, AAS, HL, CPCTC)
    4. Triangle properties (medians, altitudes, concurrencies at various “centers”, Angle Bisector Theorem)
    5. Equidistance Theorems and Midline Theorem
    6. Quadrilaterals (including the hierarchy)
    7. Polygons and polyhedra (including isosceles triangles, angles & diagonals in regular polygons, and Platonic solids)
    8. Similar figures and proportions (including similar right triangles)
    9. Pythagorean Theorem & special right triangles
    10. Right-triangle trigonometry
    11. Equations of lines, midpoints, slopes, intersections, distance
    12. Circles (radii, chords, arcs, angles, tangents, power of the point, sectors, circular segments)
    13. Area (including surface area), perimeter, and volume (including ratios of areas and volumes)
    No retakes!

You will also want to start reviewing for the final exam. We will be working on this final review packet in class but you should get started on it at home.

All the Algebra II teachers will be offering optional 45-minute review sessions (open to students of all teachers) on the review days and the first two days of final exams:
Unit 1: Quadratics Thursday 6/7 3:00 - 3:45 Mr. Gacs in Room 8
Unit 2: Exponents & Logs Friday 6/8 3:00 - 3:45 Ms. Fierabend in Room 4

Unit 4: Crypto & Number Theory Tuesday 6/12 3:00 - 3:45 Mr. Davidson in Room 5

table.name: assgts_2010_on
table.column:
Your Final Exam is on this day!

Practice for the final exam. The best way to do this is to go back over old tests and quizzes, covering up your solutions and seeing whether you can still do the problems. Redoing old assignments will also be very useful. Finally, be sure you have completed the final review packet. Answers are posted here: final review answer key

Then final exam will begin promptly at 8:50am in the following rooms:

     G block: Room 228
     H block: Room 29

     If you are a student who gets extra time(G or H block), your exam will start promptly at 7:50am in Room 7.

On the exam you will be allowed to use a calculator, and two 3"-by-5" or 4"-by-6" notecards written in your own handwriting. We recommend one unit per notecard side, since we’ve studied four units:
     * Quadratics
     * Exponents & Logs
     * Systems of Equations & Inequalities
     * Crypto & Number Theory


You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:

     1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.
     2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.
     3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
     4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.
     5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.
     6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.
     7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved, and by how much.
     8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.
     9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.
     10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.
     11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.
     12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.
     13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.
     14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.
     15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.
     16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.
     17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.
     18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.
     19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.
     20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.
     21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.
     22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.
     23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.
     24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).
     25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.
     26. Graph linear inequalities.
     27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.
     28. Use the mod operation correctly.
     29. Encipher and decipher with Caesar, substitution, affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers. (You will not need to do the exact RSA calculations as part of the exam — you already did them outside of class in RSA Part Four — but you do need to be able to follow the steps in the process.)
     30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.
     31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.
     32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.
     33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.
